'''Robert Snodgrass''' (born 7 September 1987) is a Scottish professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Winger (soccer)|winger]] for [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] and the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]]. He can also play as a [[forward (association football)|forward]].
Snodgrass started his senior career with [[Livingston F.C.|Livingston]]. He also had a loan spell at [[Stirling Albion F.C.|Stirling Albion]] before moving to England in 2008, joining [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]]. He helped Leeds win promotion to the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] in 2010. In February 2012, Snodgrass was appointed [[Captain (association football)|captain]] of Leeds, but he rejected a new contract offer and moved to [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in July. He left Norwich after they were relegated in 2014 and moved to [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]. On his league debut for Hull, Snodgrass suffered a serious knee injury that sidelined him for over a year. Hull were relegated in his absence, but Snodgrass helped them gain promotion via the playoffs in 2016. Snodgrass moved to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in January 2017.
After playing for Scotland at various youth levels including under-21s, Snodgrass received a call up to the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]] side in 2009,<ref name = "2009 callup">{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1217397/Celtic-star-Danny-Fox-Leeds-winger-Robert-Snodgrass-called-Scotland-George-Burleys-boys-head-Japan.html | work=Mail Online| title=Celtic star Danny Fox and Leeds winger Robert Snodgrass called up for Scotland as George Burley's boys head to Japan | date=1 October 2009}}</ref> and won his first cap in February 2011.<ref name=ScoNIFeb2011>{{cite news|url=http://sport.scotsman.com/scotlandsfootballteam/How-Scotland-rated-against-Northern.6715094.jp?articlepage=2 |title=How Scotland rated against Northern Ireland |publisher=Johnston Publishing|work=Scotsman.com |date=9 February 2011 |accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref>
==Early life== Born in [[Glasgow]], Snodgrass grew up in the city's [[Gallowgate, Glasgow|Gallowgate]] area;<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31495582 |title=Scotland's Robert Snodgrass on the 'hardest task' of his life |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |first=Richard |last=Wilson |date=16 February 2015 |accessdate=28 January 2017}}</ref> he played boys club football for a team affiliated with [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] alongside future international teammate [[James McArthur]] who is a month younger and lived a few blocks away.<ref name=roots>{{cite web |url=https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/robert-snodgrass-grassroots-football-glasgow-7592004 |title=Robert Snodgrass: Grassroots football in Glasgow was tough... but it is brilliant |work=Daily Record|date=20 March 2016|accessdate=11 July 2018}}</ref> [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] offered him an apprenticeship, along with [[Clyde F.C.|Clyde]] and [[Livingston F.C.|Livingston]]. He felt that he had little chance of breaking through at [[Celtic Park|Parkhead]], so chose Livingston, joining their setup at the same time as another East End boy who would go on to play for Scotland, [[Graham Dorrans]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livingston-mad.co.uk/feat/edz6/robert_snodgrass_interview_210608/index.shtml |title=Robert Snodgrass Interview|publisher=Digital Sports Group|work=Livi Mad |date=10 March 2005|accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Livingston=== Snodgrass started his career at Livingston, where he scored 15 goals in 79 league games. He caught attention by turning down a trial with Spanish giants [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]].<ref name=BarcelonaTag>{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Baillie|date=25 June 2007|url=http://sport.scotsman.com/under20worldcup/Snodgrass-aims-to-put-Barcelona.3298548.jp|title=Snodgrass aims to put Barcelona tag behind him|work=Scotsman.com|publisher=Johnston Publishing|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Before he turned professional, he was offered a move to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], though he chose to stay with Livingston.<ref>{{cite news|first=Alex|last=Livie|date=|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11676_2311276,00.html|title=Livi starlet snubbed Rovers|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=25 July 2008}}</ref> After recovering from a broken metatarsal, he moved to [[Stirling Albion F.C.|Stirling Albion]] on [[loan (association football)|loan]] for the remainder of the [[2006–07 in Scottish football|2006–07 season]] on 30 January 2007 to step up his recovery from injury.<ref name=BarcelonaTag/>
Snodgrass established himself as a regular first-team member during the [[2005–06 in Scottish football|2005–06 season]]. This was a campaign of mixed fortunes, as he gained regular first-team football, yet his side were relegated to [[Scottish First Division|Division 1]]. During Livingston's first season in the second tier, he scored ten goals for Livingston in the Scottish First Division during the 2007–08 season; he was offered a new contract at Livingston, but turned it down. After failing to impress during a trial spell with [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/leedsunited/LEEDS-UNITED-Robert39s-at-home.4698809.jp |title=LEEDS UNITED: Robert's at home in Leeds|work=Yorkshire Evening Post |date=15 November 2008|accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> he joined [[Football League One|League One]] team [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in July 2008.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/7524992.stm|title=Snodgrass completes Leeds switch|date=25 July 2008|accessdate=29 January 2019}}</ref> He left the Lions scoring 15 goals in 79 games.
===Leeds United=== ====2008–09 season==== After joining Leeds, Snodgrass came into the side for the first game of the season to make his debut against [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]], gaining an assist after setting up [[Enoch Showunmi]]'s headed goal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scunthorpe 1 – 2 Leeds: United Victorious|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/matchreport/20080809/scunthorpe-1-leeds-2_2247678_43673| publisher=Leeds United|date=9 August 2008|accessdate=28 January 2017 |archivedate=27 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227095126/http://www.leedsunited.com/matchreport/20080809/scunthorpe-1-leeds-2_2247678_43673}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Leeds in the 5–2 [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] victory over [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} After initially struggling to hold a regular place in the starting line-up, Snodgrass established himself after a string of impressive performances throughout November and December, which saw the young winger score four goals in seven games during a poor run of form for the Yorkshire club, culminating in the sacking of manager [[Gary McAllister]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}
Leeds reached the playoffs but ultimately were knocked out of the competition after losing 2–1 on aggregate to [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/league-one/5325188/Leeds-United-1-Millwall-1-Agg-1-2-Match-report.html|work=The Telegraph|title=Leeds United 1 Millwall 1: Match report|date=14 May 2009}}</ref> He was the top assist maker in the division with 16, despite only playing regular first team football from December onwards.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} In his first season at Leeds, he scored 11 goals and got 19 assists.<ref name="leedsunited.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20101102/snoddy-on-form-elland-road-and-last-term_2247585_2205213 |title=Snoddy on Form, Elland Road, And Last Term |publisher=Leeds United FC |date=2 November 2010 |accessdate= 29 January 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101105111109/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20101102/snoddy-on-form-elland-road-and-last-term_2247585_2205213 |archivedate=5 November 2010}}</ref>
====2009–10 season==== On the eve of the season, Snodgrass signed a new four-year contract with the club.<ref>{{cite news| title = Snodgrass signs new deal at Leeds| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/8189946.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 7 August 2009| accessdate = 1 June 2012}}</ref> Snodgrass made a slow start to the season, but chipped in with two assists, one against [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] in the League Cup, and the other against [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} He bagged his first goals of the season with two against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] in the League Cup second round, sending Leeds through to the third round.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}
Snodgrass scored a late winner against [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] in a 1–0 win for Leeds for his first league goal of the season.<ref name="leedsunited.com"/>
In May 2010, he was selected in the [[Football League One|League One]] [[PFA Team of the Year]] for the 2009–10 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.givemefootball.com/league-one/pfa-divisional-team-of-the-year-league-one |title=PFA Divisional Team of the Year: League One |publisher=Sports New Media |work=Give Me Football |date=26 April 2010 |accessdate=12 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913082546/http://www.givemefootball.com/league-one/pfa-divisional-team-of-the-year-league-one |archivedate=13 September 2010 }}</ref> Snodgrass played an instrumental part as Leeds were promoted to [[Football League Championship|The Championship]] after finishing in second place in League One and thus earning automatic promotion. In his second season Snodgrass scored 10 goals in total and gained 14 assists.<ref name="leedsunited.com"/>
====2010–11 season==== [[File:Robert Snodgrass Arsenal vs Leeds FA Cup 3rd round 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|Snodgrass playing for [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in 2011]]
On 27 July 2010, Snodgrass was believed to have suffered a serious knee injury during the pre-season game away to Norwegian team [[SK Brann|Brann]] after falling victim to a horrendous challenge by [[David Nielsen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/Leeds-United-Well-act-fast.6448352.jp |title=Leeds United: We'll act fast over Snodgrass |publisher=Johnston Publishing|work=Yorkshire Evening Post |date= 29 July 2010|accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/8295479.United_suffer_Snodgrass_injury_blow |title=United suffer Snodgrass injury blow |publisher=Newsquest|work=Telegraph & Argus|date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> The knee injury ruled him out of the rest of the pre-season campaign, but after two scans on the injured knee, the injury was not as serious as first feared, but kept Snodgrass out for several weeks. Manager [[Simon Grayson]] claimed that no exact timescale had been put on Snodgrass' recovery from injury.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/8879797.stm|work=BBC Sport|title=Leeds United forward Robert Snodgrass 'back in weeks'|date=3 August 2010}}</ref> Snodgrass returned to training at the start of September 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20100909/duo-close-to-return-to-action_2247585_2148737 |title=Duo Close To Turn To Action|publisher=Leeds United|date=9 September 2010 |accessdate=28 January 2017 |archivedate=11 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100911055256/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20100909/duo-close-to-return-to-action_2247585_2148737}}</ref> To help gain match fitness after his injury, Snodgrass played 90 minutes in a closed-doors friendly against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20100914/good-news-as-united-beat-boro_2247585_2153881 |title=Good News As United Beat Boro|publisher=Leeds United|date=14 September 2010 |accessdate=28 January 2017 |archivedate=16 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100916001216/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20100914/good-news-as-united-beat-boro_2247585_2153881}}</ref> Snodgrass returned to Leeds' squad after injury when he was named on the bench the game against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]], he came on as a second-half substitute replacing [[Ross McCormack]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20100917/united-held-at-doncaster_2247585_2157209 |title=United Held at Doncaster |publisher=Leeds United |date=17 September 2010 |accessdate=28 January 2017 |archivedate=20 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100920134024/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20100917/united-held-at-doncaster_2247585_2157209}}</ref>
Snodgrass came on as a second-half substitute against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] and managed to assist Leeds' late winner for Bradley Johnson, however his game ended on a sour note when he was sent off for two yellow cards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20100925/johnson-seals-united-win_2247585_2164449 |title=Johnson Seals United Win |publisher=Leeds United publisher=Leeds United FC| date=21 January 2012 |accessdate=29 January 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120124022100/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120121/its-three-for-leeds-at-home_2247585_2584051 |archivedate=24 January 2012}}</ref>
Snodgrass was appointed [[club captain]] by new Leeds manager [[Neil Warnock]], ahead of his first game in charge against Portsmouth on 25 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120227/its-captain-snodgrass-now_2247585_2625483 |title=IT'S CAPTAIN SNODGRASS NOW!|publisher=Leeds United FC |date=27 February 2012 |accessdate=29 January 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229050929/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120227/its-captain-snodgrass-now_2247585_2625483 |archivedate=29 February 2012}}</ref> Warnock confirmed he had offered Snodgrass a new contract which would make him Leeds' highest-paid player.<ref>{{cite news|title=Snodgrass offered Leeds deal|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12691/7667451/Snodgrass-offered-Leeds-deal|publisher=Sky Sports|date=12 April 2012|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref> Snodgrass finished the season with 13 goals and the second highest amount of assists in The Championship, with 14.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statbunker.com/football/btb/index.php?PL=competition&CompID=370&statType=assist&x=20&y=5|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130203170119/http://www.statbunker.com/football/btb/index.php?PL=competition&CompID=370&statType=assist&x=20&y=5|dead-url=yes|archivedate=3 February 2013|title=Npower Championship 11/12 / Most Assists|publisher=Stat Bunker|date= 3 May 2012 |accessdate= 3 May 2012}}</ref> Snodgrass won both Leeds' Fans Player of the Year and Players' Player of the Year awards during the club's end of season awards ceremony on 28 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120430/skipper-snoddys-double-success_2247585_2754619|title=Captain picks up Player of the Year awards|publisher=Leeds United FC|date= 30 April 2012 |accessdate=29 January 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501233135/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120430/skipper-snoddys-double-success_2247585_2754619 |archivedate=1 May 2012}}</ref>
===Norwich City=== Snodgrass signed for [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on a three-year contract in July 2012 for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18986870|title=Robert Snodgrass joins Norwich City from Leeds United|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=26 July 2012|accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> He made his debut in the opening game of the season on 18 August 2012, a 5–0 defeat away to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]. Two matches later, on 1 September 2012, Snodgrass scored his first goal for the club when he scored the equaliser which saw Norwich draw 1–1 with Tottenham Hotspur.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19377918|title=Robert Snodgrass scored a dramatic late equaliser as Norwich consigned 10-man Tottenham to their worst start to a Premier League season for four years.|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=1 September 2012|accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref> He scored his second goal on 28 November, scoring a free-kick in a 1–1 draw against Southampton.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20422478 |title=Southampton 1–1 Norwich |accessdate=29 January 2017 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=28 November 2012 |first=Jeremy |last=Butler }}{{Dead link|date=December 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Snodgrass would go on to establish himself as a regular in the first team squad. After a successful campaign in which the club finished 11th in the table, he would be voted by Norwich fans as second place in the [[Norwich City F.C. Player of the Season|Player of the Season]] that season. He narrowly missed out on the trophy, which was won by [[Sébastien Bassong]] instead.
Snodgrass scored his first goal of the 2013–14 season with a "free-kick from around 20 yards that looped over the wall and into the bottom-left corner of the net" in a 3–1 win over [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 9 November.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/matchday/matches/2013-2014/epl.html/norwich-vs-west-ham |title=Norwich 3–1 West Ham |publisher=Premier League |date=9 November 2013 |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> He scored again on 23 February 2014 against Tottenham after a cutting through ball from Bradley Johnson, holding off the defender and placing it past goalkeeper [[Hugo Lloris]] from just inside the box. That goal turned out to be the only goal, as Norwich won 1–0.
===Hull City=== [[File:Robert Snodgrass 21-07-2014 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Snodgrass playing for [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] in 2014]]
On 30 June 2014, Hull City signed Snodgrass for an undisclosed fee, believed to exceed £6 million, on a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28040408 |title=Robert Snodgrass: Hull City sign Scotland midfielder from Norwich |work=BBC Sport |date=30 June 2014|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref> Snodgrass dislocated a kneecap during a 1–0 win at [[Queen's Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in August 2014.<ref name = "kneecap"/> The injury, which required surgery to heal, was initially expected to keep Snodgrass out of action for several months.<ref name = "kneecap">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28824194 |title=Robert Snodgrass: Hull boss Steve Bruce confirms six-month lay-off |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=20 August 2014 |accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> A month later, it was reported that he would be out of action for the entirety of the [[2014–15 Hull City A.F.C. season|2014–15 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11714/9461836/hull-citys-robert-snodgrass-rues-season-ending-knee-injury |title=Premier League: Hull City's Robert Snodgrass rues season-ending knee injury |first=Pete |last=O'Rourke |work=Sky Sports |publisher=BSkyB |date=15 September 2014 |accessdate=10 November 2015}}</ref> Snodgrass made his first appearance in a game since the injury in November 2015, playing in an under-21 Premier League Cup match.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hulldailymail.co.uk/robert-snodgrass-player-watch-hull-city-relieved/story-28143456-detail/story.html |title=Robert Snodgrass player-watch: Hull City relieved with promising showing on return |first=James |last=Smailes |work=Hull Daily Mail |publisher= |date=9 November 2015 |accessdate=29 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208083646/http://www.hulldailymail.co.uk/Robert-Snodgrass-player-watch-Hull-City-relieved/story-28143456-detail/story.html |archivedate=8 December 2015 }}</ref> His first return to first-team action was in the [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]] away to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on 1 December 2015 when he came on as a replacement for [[Sone Aluko]] in the 73rd-minute.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34907256| title = Man City 4–1 Hull| date = 1 December 2015| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 1 December 2015}}</ref> On 9 January 2016, in the third-round of the [[FA Cup]] match against Brighton & Hove Albion, he scored a penalty to take the team through the next round.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35211426| title = Hull 1–0 Brighton| date = 9 January 2016| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 9 January 2016}}</ref> On 10 December 2016 Snodgrass won a penalty in a crucial home tie against Crystal Palace. Replays showed that he dived and he later apologized.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38277655 |title=Robert Snodgrass: Hull winger apologises for winning first-half penalty |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=10 December 2016 |accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref>
In January 2017, Hull accepted offers of about £10 million for Snodgrass from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham]] and [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38755703 |title=Robert Snodgrass: West Ham bid more than Burnley for Hull midfielder |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=26 January 2017 |accessdate=26 January 2017}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== On 27 January 2017, Snodgrass joined [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on a three-and-a-half-year deal for a fee of £10.2 million.<ref>{{cite web |title=Robert Snodgrass: West Ham sign Hull midfielder for £10.2m |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38775507 |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport |date=27 January 2017 |accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> He made his West Ham debut on 1 February 2017, coming on as a 64th-minute substitute for [[Pedro Obiang]], in West Ham's 0–4 home defeat by [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38740421|title=West Ham United 0–4 Manchester City|date=1 February 2017|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref> His first start for the club came away at Saint Mary's Stadium against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], which [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham]] won 1–3.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38779644|title=Southampton 1–3 West Ham United|date=4 February 2017|newspaper=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref> In August 2017, having played 15 games for West Ham without scoring, Snodgrass was told that he was free to leave the club either permanently or on loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40968378|title=Robert Snodgrass: West Ham winger is told he can leave the club|date=17 August 2017|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref>
Snodgrass spent most of the 2017–18 season on loan at [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], after which he returned to West Ham. He scored his first two goals for West Ham in their 8–0 win against [[Macclesfield Town F.C.|Macclesfield Town]] in the [[EFL Cup]] on 26 September 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45569334|title=West Ham 8–0 Macclesfield: Hammers thrash Macclesfield to reach fourth round|date=26 September 2018|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 September 2018}}</ref>
====Aston Villa loan==== On 25 August 2017, Snodgrass joined [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] for the remainder of the 2017–18 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2017/august/25-august/snodgrass-joins-aston-villa-season-long-loan|title=Snodgrass joins Aston Villa on season-long loan |date = 25 August 2017|accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref> Snodgrass impressed with his early performances for Aston Villa winning praise from manager, [[Steve Bruce]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.90min.com/posts/5596519-aston-villa-boss-steve-bruce-hails-impact-of-robert-snodgrass-after-victory-over-burton|title=Aston Villa Boss Steve Bruce Hails Impact of Robert Snodgrass After Victory Over Burton|date=27 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club in a 4–0 win over [[Burton Albion]] on 26 September.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41315200|title=Burton Albion 0–4 Aston Villa|publisher=BBC|date=26 September 2017 |accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref>
During his loan spell he scored seven goals and got 14 assists, to help Aston Villa secure a play-off place and defeat [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in the two semi finals to reach [[2018 EFL Championship play-off Final|the final]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44035613 |title=Aston Villa 0–0 Middlesbrough |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 May 2018 |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> playing in the final, as Villa lost 1–0 to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in the final missing out on promotion to the [[Premier League]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44178427 |title=Aston Villa 0–1 Fulham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2018 |accessdate=28 May 2018}}</ref> His 14 assists also saw him finish joint top (with [[Barry Douglas]]) of the assists charts in the [[EFL Championship]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/assists/eng-championship-2017-2018/|title=Championship 2017/2018 » Assists|publisher=World Football|date=25 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Snodgrass vs Brazil (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Snodgrass playing for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] in 2011]]
Snodgrass is a former [[Scotland national under-19 football team|Scotland under-19]], [[Scotland national under-20 football team|under-20]] and [[Scotland national under-21 football team|under-21]] international. With the under-19 team, he was part of the squad that reached the final of the [[2006 European Under-19 Football Championship|2006 European Championships]] in Poland, although Snodgrass was suspended for the final itself.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/5221720.stm |title=Scotland U19 1–2 Spain U19 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=29 July 2006 |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> Snodgrass also played for [[Scotland national under-20 football team|Scotland under-20]] in the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in [[Canada]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6270034.stm |title=Scotland U20 0–2 Nigeria U20 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |first=Clive |last=Lindsay |date=5 July 2007|accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> It was his form in this tournament that led to Barcelona showing interest in Snodgrass.<ref name="McColl"/>
Leeds' involvement in the play-offs against Millwall in 2009 meant that Snodgrass was unavailable to play in a [[Scotland B national football team|Scotland B]] international.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leeds star Robert Snodgrass determined to force way back into Scotland reckoning|work=Daily Record|date=28 October 2010|accessdate=10 February 2011|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/football/scotland/2010/10/28/leeds-star-robert-snodgrass-determined-to-force-way-back-into-scotland-reckoning-86908-22663926/}}</ref>
Snodgrass was called up to the senior [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] squad by [[George Burley]] for the first time for their [[Exhibition game|friendly]] against [[Japan national football team|Japan]] in October 2009.<ref name = "2009 callup"/> He was forced to withdraw from the squad due to a knee injury.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/leedsunited/Leeds-United-Does-Scotland-call.6618351.jp|title=Leeds United: Does Scotland call up beckon for Snodgrass?|work=Yorkshire Evening Post|date=9 November 2010|quote=A knee injury came between Snodgrass and his international debut 13 months ago and the landscape north of the border has shifted since then. George Burley – the coach who planned to play Snodgrass in a friendly in Japan – lost his job late last year; his successor, Craig Levein, is yet to bring the winger on board. |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Snodgrass made his full international debut on 9 February 2011, coming on as a substitute against [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]] in a [[2011 Nations Cup]] match.<ref name=ScoNIFeb2011/> Snodgrass was called up to the Scotland squad to face [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] on 21 March 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20110321/two-more-set-for-international-duty_2247585_2320791 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110323115220/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20110321/two-more-set-for-international-duty_2247585_2320791 |dead-url=yes |archivedate=23 March 2011 |title=TWO MORE SET FOR INTERNATIONAL DUTY |publisher=Leeds United |date=21 March 2011 |accessdate=23 March 2011 }}</ref> coming on as a second-half substitute. Scotland lost the game 2–0.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/9431234.stm | work=BBC Sport | title=Scotland 0–2 Brazil | date=27 March 2011|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref> Snodgrass was ruled out of Scotland's Nations Cup matches against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] and the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] with a back injury.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20110517/striker-ross-gets-international-call_2247585_2361498 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521144359/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20110517/striker-ross-gets-international-call_2247585_2361498 |dead-url=yes |archivedate=21 May 2011 |title=STRIKER ROSS GETS INTERNATIONAL CALL |publisher=Leeds United |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=18 May 2011 }}</ref>
On 2 August 2011, Snodgrass was called up to the squad for a friendly against [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]].<ref name="leedsunited3"/> He made his first start for Scotland against Denmark and also scored his first international goal in this game.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/9561341.stm | work=BBC Sport | first=Martin | last=Conaghan | title=Scotland v Denmark as it happened | date=10 August 2011| accessdate=10 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/14481694.stm | work=BBC Sport | title=Snodgrass pleased with debut goal | date=10 August 2011 | accessdate=10 August 2011}}</ref> On 7 June 2013, during [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|2014 FIFA World Cup qualifying]], he scored the only goal in a 1–0 win against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]], inflicting their first competitive defeat at home since they lost 4–1 to [[England national football team|England]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22787925 |title=Croatia 0–1 Scotland|work= BBC Sport|date= 7 June 2013|accessdate= 8 June 2013}}</ref>
The kneecap injury that Snodgrass suffered in August 2014 caused him to miss the whole of the [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] campaign. He was recalled to the national squad for a friendly match against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] in March 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35866870 |first=Richard |last=Wilson |title=Scotland v Czech Republic: I'm back at my previous level – Snodgrass |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=21 March 2016 |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> In the first match of [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification]], Snodgrass scored a hat-trick in a 5–1 win against [[Malta national football team|Malta]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37207612 |title=Malta 1–5 Scotland |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |first=Alasdair |last=Lamont |date=4 September 2016 |accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== Snodgrass has a daughter, Sienna, with his girlfriend Denise.<ref name="McColl">{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/scotland/article1779973.ece |work=Times Online| title=Stirling provide the spark as Snodgrass gets back on track | first=Graham | last=McColl | date=12 May 2007|accessdate=28 May 2010}}{{subscription}}</ref>
On 24 January 2011, an arrest warrant was issued for Snodgrass after he failed to turn up to court regarding an alleged driving offence.<ref name = "arrest">{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/news/BREAKING-Arrest-warrant-out-for.6700820.jp|title=Arrest warrant out for Leeds United winger|last=Robinson|first=Paul|work=Yorkshire Evening Post|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> A spokesman for Leeds United said that the non-appearance was due to a misunderstanding and that Snodgrass was working with the judicial authorities to resolve the matter.<ref name = "arrest"/>
On 3 March 2017, another arrest warrant was issued for him after he failed to attend his trial for allegedly driving in Glasgow with a baby being held in the arms of a passenger. His defence lawyer said that Snodgrass' absence was due to a misunderstanding.<ref>{{cite news|title=Warrant issued for Scotland footballer Snodgrass over baby in car|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-39156677|accessdate=4 March 2017|publisher=BBC News|date=3 March 2017}}</ref>
